time_markers.text: since my times as the secretary-general of the OAU
quotes: I would like to thank all African colleagues here, who for many years since my times as the secretary-general of the OAU have been supportive and active in our collective efforts and struggles in the service of our continent.
and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.
GM Khadiagala, Allies in adversity: The frontline states in southern African security, 1975–1993, Athens: Ohio University Press, 1994, 25.
Created in 1961, the NAM emerged as a body of independent states that sought to remain unaffiliated with the power struggles between the US and the Soviet Union during the Cold War.
K Matthews, Tanzania and the United Nations, Utafiti, 5:2, 1980, www.archive.lib.msu.edu/DMC/African%20Journals/pdfs/Utafiti/vol5no2/aejp005002003.pdf, 209 (accessed 4 May 2014).
See PAFMECA, International Organisation, 16:2, 1962, University of Wisconsin Press, www.jstor.org/stable/2705401 (accessed 10 March 2015).
AA Mazrui, Anti-militarism and political militancy in Tanzania, The Journal of Conflict Resolution, 12:3, 1968, www.jstor.org/stable/172666, 276 (accessed 6 May 2014).
See Nuclear Treaty Initiative, www.nti.org/treaties-and-regimes/non-aligned-movement-nam/ (accessed 10 March 2015).

roles.title: secretary-general
quotes: I would like to thank all African colleagues here, who for many years since my times as the secretary-general of the OAU have been supportive and active in our collective efforts and struggles in the service of our continent.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.

The Pan-African Freedom Movement of East and Central Africa (PAFMECA) initially comprised representatives of political parties from Kenya, the then Nyasaland (Malawi), the then Tanganyika (Tanzania), Uganda, and Zanzibar, and by 1962 expanded to include over 50 representatives from independent African states, political parties, and liberation movements.
GM Khadiagala, Allies in adversity: The frontline states in southern African security, 1975–1993, Athens: Ohio University Press, 1994, 25.
